1074243020793503744.text:
Do you want to challenge your understanding of #money?
A hundred years ago A. Mitchell Innes showed his take on the #credit theory of money in 25 points.
Do you think you can understand money as well as he did all those years ago?
This thread is made of all those points.

1077211206023344129.text:
A test version of Ether Bank client is ready!
https://github.com/ideal-money/etherbank-cli/ …
Give it a look and get your free loans on Ropsten for now!

1074566647007072256.text: Here's the link to the whole article. Be sure to check it out if you want to dive deeper into the sea.https://medium.com/ideal-money/the-credit-theory-of-money-9d141640465d …

1074243058722619392.text: 25. The depreciation of money is the cause of rising prices.

1074243057103572993.text:
23. Large reserves of "lawful money'' in the banks are evidence of an inflation of the government currency.

24. The  inflation of government money induces a still greater inflation of  credit throughout the country, and a consequent general depreciation of  money.

1074243055513931776.text: 22. The issue of coins in exchange for gold at a fixed and excessive  price, without providing taxes for their redemption, causes an inflation  of government money, and thus causes an excessive floating debt and a  depreciation of government money.

1074243053840416769.text: 21. The nominal value of the dollar coin exceeds the market value of the  gold of which it is made. Coins can only remain in circulation for any  length of time if their nominal value exceeds their intrinsic value.

1074243052418551809.text: 20. The governments of the world have conspired together to make a corner in gold and hold it up at an excessive price.

1074243050837299200.text:
18. The "reserves of lawful money" in the banks have no more importance than any other bank asset.

19. Laws of legal tender promote panics.

1074243049319030784.text: 17. The redemption of paper money in gold coin is not redemption at all, but merely the exchange of one form of obligation for another of an identical nature.

1074243047632855040.text: 16. The government stamp on a piece of gold changes the character of the gold from that of a mere commodity to that of a token of indebtedness.

1074243046080897025.text: 15. Government money is redeemed by taxation.

1074243044466155520.text: 14. Debts due at a certain moment can only be off-set against credits which become available at that moment.

1074243042993934336.text: 13. The value of credit does not depend on the existence of gold behind it, but on the solvency of the debtor.

1074243041500778496.text: 12. The precious metals are not a standard of value.

1074243040083095553.text: 11. Until modern days, there never was any fixed relationship between the monetary unit and the coinage.

1074243038325735424.text: 10. b. ...this depreciation which was due to wars, pestilences and famines - in short to excessive indebtedness.

1074243036580859904.text: 10. a. The depreciation of money in the middle ages was not due to the arbitrary debasement of the weight and fineness of the coins. On the contrary, the government of the middle ages struggled against....

1074243034777309187.text: 9. The issue of money is not an exclusive privilege of government, but merely one of its functions, as a great buyer of services and commodities. Money in one form or another is, in fact, issued by banks, merchants, etc.

1074243033200295937.text: 8. A coin is an instrument of credit or token of indebtedness; identical in its nature with a tally or with any other form of money, by whomsoever issued.

1074243031522574337.text: 7. A banker is one who centralizes the debts of mankind and cancels them against one another. Banks are the clearing houses of commerce.

1074243030020997120.text: 6. The object of commerce is the acquisition of credits.

1074243028397768704.text: 5. A credit cancels a debt; this is the primitive law of commerce. By sale a credit is acquired, by purchase a debt is created. Purchases, therefore, are paid for by sales.

1074243026871029760.text: 4. The monetary unit is an abstract standard for the measurement of credit and debt. It is liable to fluctuation and only remains stable if the law of the equation of credits and debts is observed.

1074243025327538176.text: 3. Credit and credit alone is money.

1074243023918284801.text: 2. A sale and purchase is the exchange of a commodity for a credit.

1074243022353776640.text: 1. There is no such thing as a medium of exchange.
